oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Asclepiasspeciosa (Apocynaceae, Asclepiadoideae): a rare or unrecognized alien species in Europe?
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gudžinskas, Zigmantas
Petrulaitis, Lukas
Žalneravičius, Egidijus
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>Studies on populations of <jats:italic>Asclepiassyriaca</jats:italic> L. in Lithuania revealed the occurrence of a new alien plant species, the North American native <jats:italic>Asclepiasspeciosa</jats:italic> Torr. (Apocynaceae, Asclepiadoideae), in southern parts of Lithuania – the first report of the latter species in Europe. Interestingly, a thorough analysis of herbarium specimens revealed that <jats:italic>A.speciosa</jats:italic> had first been collected in Lithuania in 1962, but the specimen was misidentified at the time as <jats:italic>A.syriaca</jats:italic>. The newly discovered population of <jats:italic>A.speciosa</jats:italic> occupies mesic grasslands, tall-herb fringe communities and arable field habitats. Sexual reproduction of this species was not recorded; it spreads locally by means of vegetative reproduction. We present here an exhaustive analysis of morphological characteristics and differences between <jats:italic>A.speciosa</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>A.syriaca</jats:italic> and other species of the genus, as well as a key for identification of alien <jats:italic>Asclepias</jats:italic> species in Europe. We predict that the effect of <jats:italic>A.speciosa</jats:italic> on native habitats and communities, and its economic impact, are comparable to those of the highly invasive <jats:italic>A.syriaca</jats:italic>. Although <jats:italic>A.speciosa</jats:italic> currently occurs very rarely as an alien species in Europe, its existence in other regions of Europe is highly probable.</jats:p>
